commentBody:
I didn't have time to read past the first example (yet I have time to post a comment, go figure...), but the problem with that one is pretty obvious, and it's not what Corbett says. "Meetings" can't be the object of the verb "hashed out" since it is the object of the preposition "of". Instead, the subject of "hashed out" is the noun "series".

Most people, when first reading that sentence, will assume that the word "after" is a preposition since it is closely followed by a noun ("series"), which is presumably its object, with no verb in sight. Only when the reader gets to the verb "hashed out" will he realize that something is wrong. That is why the sentence is so awkward. Only at that point will the reader, if he has the patience, go back and realize that "after" is actually a subordinating conjunction with "series" as the subject of the dependent clause.
